#Text=III
#Text=At supper that night , holiday talk held undisputed sway .
#Text=Mr. Pritchard spoke of “ Scotland , ” Miss Isaacs clamoured of Bettws-y-Coed , Mr. Judson displayed a proprietary interest in the Norfolk Broads .
#Text=“ I ? ” said Hoopdriver when the question came to him .
#Text=“ Why , cycling , of course . ”
#Text=“ You ’re never going to ride that dreadful machine of yours , day after day ? ” said Miss Howe of the Costume Department .
#Text=“ I am , ” said Hoopdriver as calmly as possible , pulling at the insufficient moustache .
#Text=“ I ’m going for a Cycling Tour .
#Text=Along the South Coast . ”
#Text=“ Well , all I hope , Mr. Hoopdriver , is that you ’ll get fine weather , ” said Miss Howe .
#Text=“ And not come any nasty croppers . ”
#Text=“ And done forget some tinscher of arnica in yer bag , ” said the junior apprentice in the very high collar .
#Text=( He had witnessed one of the lessons at the top of Putney Hill . )
#Text=“ You stow it , ” said Mr. Hoopdriver , looking hard and threateningly at the junior apprentice , and suddenly adding in a tone of bitter contempt , -- “Jampot . ”
#Text=“ I ’m getting fairly safe upon it now , ” he told Miss Howe .
#Text=At other times Hoopdriver might have further resented the satirical efforts of the apprentice , but his mind was too full of the projected Tour to admit any petty delicacies of dignity .
#Text=He left the supper table early , so that he might put in a good hour at the desperate gymnastics up the Roehampton Road before it would be time to come back for locking up .
#Text=When the gas was turned off for the night he was sitting on the edge of his bed , rubbing arnica into his knee -- a new and very big place -- and studying a Road Map of the South of England .
#Text=Briggs of the “ dresses , ” who shared the room with him , was sitting up in bed and trying to smoke in the dark .
#Text=Briggs had never been on a cycle in his life , but he felt Hoopdriver ’s inexperience and offered such advice as occurred to him .
#Text=“ Have the machine thoroughly well oiled , ” said Briggs , “ carry one or two lemons with you , do n’t tear yourself to death the first day , and sit upright .
#Text=Never lose control of the machine , and always sound the bell on every possible opportunity .
#Text=You mind those things , and nothing very much ca n’t happen to you , Hoopdriver -- you take my word . ”
#Text=He would lapse into silence for a minute , save perhaps for a curse or so at his pipe , and then break out with an entirely different set of tips .
#Text=“ Avoid running over dogs , Hoopdriver , whatever you do .
#Text=It ’s one of the worst things you can do to run over a dog .

#Text=Never let the machine buckle -- there was a man killed only the other day through his wheel buckling -- do n’t scorch , do n’t ride on the foot-path , keep your own side of the road , and if you see a tramline , go round the corner at once , and hurry off into the next county -- and always light up before dark .
#Text=You mind just a few little things like that , Hoopdriver , and nothing much ca n’t happen to you -- you take my word . ”
#Text=“ Right you are ! ” said Hoopdriver .
#Text=“ Good-night , old man . ”
#Text=“ Good-night , ” said Briggs , and there was silence for a space , save for the succulent respiration of the pipe .
#Text=Hoopdriver rode off into Dreamland on his machine , and was scarcely there before he was pitched back into the world of sense again .
#Text=--
#Text=Somethingwhat was it ?
#Text=“ Never oil the steering .
#Text=It ’s fatal , ” a voice that came from round a fitful glow of light , was saying .
#Text=“ And clean the chain daily with black-lead .
#Text=You mind just a few little things like that -- ”
#Text=“ Lord LOVE us ! ” said Hoopdriver , and pulled the bedclothes over his ears .
#Text=IV .
#Text=THE RIDING FORTH OF MR .
#Text=HOOPDRIVER

#Text=Only those who toil six long days out of the seven , and all the year round , save for one brief glorious fortnight or ten days in the summer time , know the exquisite sensations of the First Holiday Morning .
#Text=All the dreary , uninteresting routine drops from you suddenly , your chains fall about your feet .

#Text=All at once you are Lord of yourself , Lord of every hour in the long , vacant day ; you may go where you please , call none Sir or Madame , have a lappel free of pins , doff your black morning coat , and wear the colour of your heart , and be a Man .
#Text=You grudge sleep , you grudge eating , and drinking even , their intrusion on those exquisite moments .

#Text=There will be no more rising before breakfast in casual old clothing , to go dusting and getting ready in a cheerless , shutter-darkened , wrappered-up shop , no more imperious cries of , “ Forward , Hoopdriver , ” no more hasty meals , and weary attendance on fitful old women , for ten blessed days .
#Text=The first morning is by far the most glorious , for you hold your whole fortune in your hands .
#Text=Thereafter , every night , comes a pang , a spectre , that will not be exorcised -- the premonition of the return .
#Text=The shadow of going back , of being put in the cage again for another twelve months , lies blacker and blacker across the sunlight .
#Text=But on the first morning of the ten the holiday has no past , and ten days seems as good as infinity .

#Text=And it was fine , full of a promise of glorious days , a deep blue sky with dazzling piles of white cloud here and there , as though celestial haymakers had been piling the swathes of last night ’s clouds into cocks for a coming cartage .
#Text=There were thrushes in the Richmond Road , and a lark on Putney Heath .
#Text=The freshness of dew was in the air ; dew or the relics of an overnight shower glittered on the leaves and grass .
#Text=Hoopdriver had breakfasted early by Mrs. Gunn ’s complaisance .
#Text=He wheeled his machine up Putney Hill , and his heart sang within him .
#Text=Halfway up , a dissipated-looking black cat rushed home across the road and vanished under a gate .
#Text=All the big red-brick houses behind the variegated shrubs and trees had their blinds down still , and he would not have changed places with a soul in any one of them for a hundred pounds .
